Little Sister Snow
by Frances Little

4.text:
Recording by Claudia Salto
CHAPTER I

8.text:
A quaint old Japanese garden lay smiling under
the sunshine of a morning in early spring.

17.text:
The sun, having flooded the outside world
with dazzling light, seemed to sink to a tender

24.text:
radiance as it wooed leaf and bud into new
life and loveliness. It loosened the tiny

32.text:
rivulet from the icy fingers of winter, and
sped it merrily on its way to a miniature

40.text:
lake, where shining goldfish darted here and
there in an ecstasy of motion. It stole into

48.text:
the shadows of a great pine-tree, and touched
the white wings of the pigeons as they cooed

56.text:
the song of mating-time. It gleamed on the
sandy path that led to the old stone lantern,

64.text:
played into the eyes of Kwannon, the Goddess
of Mercy, and finally lost itself in the trees

72.text:
beyond.
Under a gnarled plum-tree, that for uncounted

77.text:
years had braved the snow and answered joyously
the first call of spring, a little maiden

85.text:
stood and held out eager hands to catch the
falling blossoms. The flowering-time was nearly

93.text:
done, and the child stood watching the petals
twirl quickly down, filling the hollows and

100.text:
fashioning curious designs on the mossy grass.
The softest of breezes coming across the river,

108.text:
over the thick hedge, saucily blew a stray
petal straight into the child's face. To Yuki

116.text:
Chan it was a challenge, and with outstretched
hands and flying feet she gave chase to the

124.text:
whirling blossoms. Round and round the old
tree, into the hedge, and up the sandy path

132.text:
she raced, her long sleeves spreading like
tiny sails, her cheeks flushed to the same

140.text:
crimson as her flowery playmates. A sudden
stillness in the air ended the romp. Yuki

148.text:
Chan returned to her playground beneath the
tree, and taking her captured petals from

154.text:
the folds of her kimono, began to count her
trophies.

159.text:
"Ichi, ni, san, ichi, ni, san," she rhythmically
droned, three being the magical number that

169.text:
would bring good luck if the petals were properly
arranged and the number repeated often enough.

177.text:
But the monotony of repetition brought rest,
and soon Yuki Chan, forgetting to count, made

186.text:
a bed of the fallen petals and turned her
face toward the little straw-roofed house

192.text:
from which noises of busy preparation came.
It was a birthday. Not Yuki Chan's, for that

201.text:
came with the snow-time. This was the third
day of the third month, which in the long

208.text:
ago was set apart as the big birthday of all
little girls born in the lovely island, and

216.text:
was celebrated by the Festival of Dolls.
Yuki Chan lay with her slim body stretched

224.text:
in the warmth of the sun. In every graceful
line was the imprint of high breeding; her

231.text:
white face, so unusual with her race, was
stamped with the romance and tragedy of centuries;

239.text:
while her eyes, limpid and luminous, looked
out at the world with eager, questioning interest.

250.text:
Through the wide-open shoji of the house she
caught glimpses of her father and mother hurrying

258.text:
and holding consultations. She marked frequent
visits to the old warehouse that held the

265.text:
household treasures, and the bringing out
of bundles wrapped in yellow cloth. The air

271.text:
brought her whiffs of cooking food, and the
flower- and fish-men deposited a fair part

278.text:
of their stock on the porch. But Yuki Chan
was banished from these joys of preparation

286.text:
because of naughtiness, and as she lay in
the warm sunshine she thought of her recent

293.text:
wickedness. She smiled as she remembered how
she had hid her father's pipe that he might

302.text:
work the faster, and broken the straps of
her mother's wooden shoes, so that she could

309.text:
not go outdoors. She laughed softly when she
thought of the stray cat which she had brought

316.text:
into the house and coaxed to drink milk while
she, with skilful fingers and a pair of scissors,

325.text:
transformed her smooth fur into a wonderful
landscape garden. Short work had made kitty's

333.text:
head slick and shiny, like a lake, with a
stray bristle or two, which stood for trees.

341.text:
In the middle of her back stood Fuji, the
great mountain, with numberless little Fujis

348.text:
to keep company. Many winding paths ran down
kitty's legs to queer, shapeless shrines,

356.text:
and it was only when Yuki Chan had insisted
on making a curious old pine-tree with twisted

364.text:
limbs of kitty's short and stubby tail that
trouble ensued, and she had been requested

372.text:
by her mother to take her honorable little
body to the garden.

378.text:
Yuki Chan remembered her mother's beautiful
smile of love as she gently chided her, and

384.text:
recalled the note of trouble in the kind voice.
Was the mother sorry because she had stuck

392.text:
out a very pink tongue at a cross-eyed old
image that sat on the floor on the very spot

398.text:
that she wanted to step upon? Or was it—and
Yuki Chan grew grave—that the last go rin

409.text:
had been spent for the new dress she was to
wear that day?

413.text:
All her short life Yuki Chan had lived in
a house of love, but no veil of affection,

422.text:
no sacrifice, could shield her from the knowledge
of poverty. She had never seen her mother

429.text:
wear but one festival dress, yet her own little
kimono was ever bright and dainty, and even

437.text:
the new brocade of the dolls' dresses stood
alone with the weave of gold and tinsel.

443.text:
A solemn thought, like a pebble dropped into
water, caused circle after circle to trouble

452.text:
her childish mind. She did not quite understand,
but she knew there was something she must

460.text:
learn. She had been naughty and weighed her
mother's spirits. She had caused a grave look

468.text:
in her father's kind eyes, and had sent the
household pets scattering with her mischief.

476.text:
Now she must be good—very good—else the
fox spirit would come upon her, and she would

483.text:
go through life an unhappy soul. She would
give more obedience to the honorable mother,

491.text:
whose every word had been a caress. It was
as if for the first time the great book of

498.text:
life opened before her and, though unconscious
of its meaning, the first word she saw spelled

508.text:
Duty.
The noises from the house grew fainter. The

513.text:
child, with blinking eyes, lay gazing straight
above her. Overhead the branches overflowed

522.text:
into a canopy of crimson, which shut out the
great real world and opened into a fairy world

532.text:
wherein only the untried feet of youth may
tread and the fragile flowers of child-dreams

540.text:
bloom. The gates thereto are slight but strong,
and only knowledge erects an impassable barrier.

549.text:
The wind sang its lullaby through the blossoms
of the tree, and sleep would soon have overtaken

557.text:
Yuki Chan had not a peculiar sound aroused
her and caused her eyes to fly wide open.

566.text:
Once before she had heard it, and it had meant
death to the big robin who lived in the branches

574.text:
above. The cry came from the mother bird this
time and brought Yuki Chan to her feet.

582.text:
Through the shower of blossoms, brought down
by the mad fluttering of wings, she saw a

589.text:
tiny half-feathered thing struggling in the
sharp claws of her lately acquired pet. With

598.text:
certainty of success, the cat let its victim
weakly flutter an inch or two away, then reaching

606.text:
out a cruel paw drew it back. Twice repeated,
the green eyes narrowed to slits, and Yuki

616.text:
Chan, horrified, saw big red drops slowly
dripping from either side of the whiskered

624.text:
mouth. Terror held her for a moment as she
heard the crunching of small bones, then white

634.text:
passion enveloped her as she stole noiselessly
from behind and closed her two small hands

641.text:
around the furry throat.
"Baka!" she cried from between her clenched

648.text:
teeth. "Baka—to eat the baby birds! This
day will I ask Oni to make you into a stone,

659.text:
which every foot will kick and hurt, and you
can neither move nor cry. You cruel, cruel

667.text:
beast!" In vain the cat struggled. Yuki Chan
held it firmly at arm's-length while she decided

677.text:
what was to be its fate.
Looking sternly at the offender, her lips

684.text:
rounded into a long-drawn "s-o," the light
of anticipated revenge danced in her eyes.

694.text:
At last she knew what to do, O most honorable
but very ugly cat! She would throw her into

703.text:
the ditch, where great crawling frogs with
popping eyes would stick out long tongues;

711.text:
where flying things would sting, and creeping
things would bite; where the great tide would

719.text:
come later and take her out to the big, big
ocean, where there was neither milk to drink

727.text:
nor birds to eat.
At the thought of her furry playmate floating

733.text:
alone and hungry in the vast place which,
to Yuki Chan, had neither beginning nor end,

742.text:
something of pity touched her heart, and she
slightly loosened her grasp.

747.text:
The cat gained a good breath and used it.
In the fight for freedom a sharp claw was

757.text:
drawn down the child's arm, leaving a line
of red in its course. Compassion took flight,

765.text:
and Yuki Chan, clutching anew, went swiftly
down the path that led to the street, with

772.text:
a watchful eye on the lodge of the keeper
of the gate.

775.text:
The keeper was very old, and very cross, and
lately had acquired a curious idea that little

785.text:
girls must ask his honorable permission to
go in and out the gate. One day he actually

794.text:
threatened punishment, and Yuki Chan, in her
scorn, invited him to cut off his head with

802.text:
a sword, that he might save his face. Now
the way was clear.

808.text:
She turned her head and bumped her small body
against the weight of the heavy gates until

816.text:
they swung slightly apart and permitted her
to slip through.

821.text:
So intent was her purpose to reach the ditch
across the street that she did not see an

827.text:
approaching jinrikisha, and before she knew
it she had been tumbled over and sent rolling

835.text:
to the side of the road. Still clutching the
kitten, she sat up and rubbed the dust from

843.text:
her eyes.
Standing over her was the jinrikisha man,

849.text:
and beside him was his passenger, a young
American boy, whose light hair and blue eyes

857.text:
held her spell-bound. He was brushing the
dust from her kimono, and his foreign tongue

866.text:
made strange sounds.
"Say, kid," the boy was saying, as he transferred

872.text:
the dust from his hands to his handkerchief,
"glad you're not hurt or got any bones cracked.

878.text:
Where's your mama, or your papa, or your nurse,
to give you a spanking and keep you off the

885.text:
street?"
As he talked Yuki Chan grew fascinated watching

891.text:
his mouth, and forgot, for a moment, her direful
intention. The cat, again taking advantage

900.text:
of her relaxed hold, began to tug for freedom,
and a lively struggle ensued.

908.text:
The boy, looking on, began to laugh, a laugh
that began in his eyes, ran over his face

915.text:
and down into his throat, whence it came again
in a shout of boyish merriment.

922.text:
Yuki Chan, looking from him to the smiling
jinrikisha man, grew crimson with anger. With

928.text:
a swift movement she ran toward the ditch.
Divining her purpose by the look in her eyes,

937.text:
Dick Merrit went gallantly to the rescue of
the kitten. He was tall for his sixteen years,

946.text:
and his long strides more than matched the
pattering steps of the slip of a girl who

952.text:
raced before him.
"No, you don't, kiddie," he cried; "your manicured

958.text:
cat is not going into the ditch, if we have
to scrap for it."

964.text:
Merrit caught Yuki Chan in one arm, and again
and again loosened her fingers from the struggling

974.text:
kitten.
"Iya, Iya!" the child screamed; but Merrit,

979.text:
as determined as she, held her firmly, and
ended by lightly slapping first one little

987.text:
hand and then the other.
The child, thus coming into contact for the

993.text:
first time with physical force, relaxed her
grasp and gazed in amazement at the boy's

1001.text:
determined face.
"I guess your 'Iya' means no, little lady,

1008.text:
and I say 'Iya' too," said Merrit, taking
the cat into his arms and smoothing its uneven

1015.text:
back. "You are not going to put it into the
ditch. Why don't you give it to me? I am getting

1025.text:
up a collection of cats and things at the
school, and I'd like to take this queer specimen

1033.text:
along. Ask her if I can have it."
The jinrikisha man, who stood a smiling spectator,

1041.text:
saw Dick Merrit's hand move toward his pocket,
and was instantly alert and eager to settle

1049.text:
the matter.
"Him ve'y bad girl," he said; "him make dead

1055.text:
for catty. You give me ten sen, I take girl
homely. You have much of catty."

1062.text:
But Dick declined all interference, and putting
the cat inside his coat he stooped down and

1070.text:
took one of Yuki Chan's unresisting hands.
Her sleeve fell back, and he saw the long

1079.text:
red scratch.
"Hello! The cat had an inning too, didn't

1084.text:
she? I'd like to chuck her for hurting you,
but I can't let you give her a bath in that

1093.text:
dirty hole. Never mind, I'll take her home,
and some day I'll bring you something. I bet

1100.text:
you don't understand a word I'm saying, but
I'll be hanged if I know how to make you."

1107.text:
Feeling rather helpless, Dick talked on, patting
first Yuki Chan and then the cat.

1114.text:
The child stood speechless and looked deep
into his eyes, not having entirely recovered

1122.text:
from the shock of the first blow she had ever
received.

1126.text:
"You'll be good, won't you?" he went on coaxingly,
"not drown any more cats and things?"

1136.text:
Yuki Chan, with the intuition that only a
child can have, suddenly bridged the gulf

1144.text:
of strange language and understood. With the
quick movement of a nestling bird, she bent

1152.text:
forward and laid her cheek against the boy's
shoulder. It was not only complete surrender,

1159.text:
but allegiance to the conqueror.
Dick rose, red and confused. Then he climbed

1167.text:
into the jinrikisha, trying to ignore the
smiles of the man.

1172.text:
Yuki Chan, with her hands joined just below
her sash, bent her body like a half-shut jack-knife.

1182.text:
"Arigato—arigato," she said politely, as
she bowed again and again.

1187.text:
"Him say t'ank you," interpreted the jinrikisha
man.

1200.text:
Yuki Chan watched the back of the jinrikisha
and the swinging brown legs of the jinrikisha

1206.text:
man that showed beneath. She had forgotten
the cat, but she still remembered the kind

1213.text:
look in the blue eyes of the boy.
"Yuki, Yuki!" came the voice of the mother

1221.text:
in her native tongue. "Come, the feast is
prepared, and the sandals are worn from my

1227.text:
feet running to seek you. Hurry! before the
red beans grow cold."

1234.text:
The child sent a long-drawn "Hei" in answer
to her mother, then to herself she said over

1245.text:
She had heard the words a few times before,
but they were associated with her visits to

1252.text:
the mission-school and a certain oblong box
out of which came sticks of red and white

1259.text:
with a very sweet taste. Now, as she said
them, a new meaning seemed to play about them.

1268.text:
She slipped through the gate and walked with
unhurried feet toward the small house, so

1275.text:
gay in its festal plumage. As she passed the
old plum-tree she looked up and saw the mother

1283.text:
bird cuddling her babies beneath her breast.
Some tender thought lighted the child's face

1291.text:
into a strange beauty, as a stray sunbeam
finds a hidden flower and glorifies it. Turning

1299.text:
her face upward to the nest, she patted her
own cheek and said: "Be goodu, Yuki, be goodu."

1310.text:
End of Chapter I
CHAPTER II

1319.text:
In the springtime a Japanese house is a fairy-like
thing, with only top and bottom of straw and

1326.text:
a few upholding posts to give it a look of
substance.

1331.text:
Yuki Chan's house was typical. The paper screens
were carefully put away during the day, that

1338.text:
the breezes might play unobstructed through
the house. At night the heavy wooden doors

1343.text:
were fitted into grooves and served not only
to keep out the night air, but also the evil

1349.text:
spirits that come abroad when the great sun
ceases watching.

1355.text:
Binding the whole was a narrow porch, showing
a floor polished like a mirror from the slipping

1361.text:
and sliding of generations of feet. Yuki Chan
first learned to know her face in its reflections

1368.text:
and, alas! by the same method had learned
the saucy fascination of sticking out her

1375.text:
small pink tongue.
On the side of the porch toward the plum-tree

1380.text:
the child found her father and mother waiting.
The two old people sat on gay cushions with

1387.text:
hands folded and feet crossed. Their festal
attire bore the marks of a once careless luxury,

1395.text:
but now shabbiness tried to hide itself under
the bravery of tinsel, where once had been

1401.text:
pure gold.
Each year the struggle of obsolete methods

1406.text:
of business and the intricacies of progress
plowed the furrows a little deeper in the

1411.text:
man's face, and when his eyes, that in youth
had blazed with ambition, grew wistful and

1418.text:
troubled, he dropped them that his wife might
not see.

1423.text:
But what silence could hide from this frail
woman any mood of the man she had served with

1428.text:
mind and body and soul these many years? When
she came to him as a shy bride on trial, she

1435.text:
knew no such word as love. Duty was her entire
vocabulary, and she asked nothing and gave

1443.text:
all.
Many little souls had come to her, with hands

1447.text:
all crimped and pink, like new-blown cherry-leaves,
only to close their eyes and pass out to the

1454.text:
good god Jizo, who is always waiting to help
little children across the river of death.

1461.text:
In years gone by, night after night sleep
had flown before the terror that another woman

1467.text:
would be brought into the house that the family
name might not die out. Silently she would

1473.text:
slip out to the little shrine and pour out
passionate words of prayer that just one little

1479.text:
soul might be permitted to live.
No matter how long the night, nor how bitter

1485.text:
the struggle, morning always found her bright
and cheerful, bending every effort to invent

1492.text:
new diversions for her husband. She labored
to anticipate every wish, and even though

1498.text:
she did without, she provided him the best
of comfort. Working far into the night, secretly

1505.text:
disposing of her small personal treasures,
acquiescing in his most trivial statements,

1511.text:
she planned that no slightest gap in the domestic
arrangement should suggest itself to him.

1518.text:
The woman worked and prayed and waited. Then
she triumphed. In the wake of a great snow-storm

1524.text:
came the longed-for child, and they called
her Yuki, after the snow that had brought

1530.text:
them their wish. Hand in hand with Yuki Chan
came love, and bound the hearts of the man

1537.text:
and woman with ties of a desire fulfilled.
From that time to this love had prevailed,

1544.text:
and as Yuki Chan climbed on the porch, besmirching
its shining surface with her muddy little

1550.text:
feet, that had been guiltless of sandals all
day, the faces of the two old people lighted

1556.text:
up with sudden joy.
Yuki Chan looked ruefully at the muddy prints

1562.text:
she had made and realized that she had been
a most impolite little girl. Remembering her

1568.text:
recent resolve, she sought the eyes in which
she had never seen any light for her save

1573.text:
that of love. She drew close, and reaching
down took her mother's hand, hard and cracked

1581.text:
by labor, and laying her cheek against it
said, with a voice sure of forgiveness and

1587.text:
sweet desire for atonement:
"Go men nasai."

1591.text:
The mother, with a courtly but playful air,
granted her pardon with a low salutation.

1599.text:
Then with a rush of affection that no convention
could stem, she folded the child to her heart

1605.text:
and lived another moment of supreme joy.
The father sat by, making no comment, his

1612.text:
eyes bright and twinkling. Then he suggested
that their Majesties, the dolls, had been

1618.text:
waiting long on the shelf. Was it not time
they were receiving a visit?

1624.text:
The years of toil were telling on both father
and mother, but they daily refreshed themselves

1629.text:
at the overbrimming fountain of Yuki Chan's
youth, and now, as they each took one of her

1636.text:
hands to go in to see the dolls, they were
so gay that the child suggested that instead

1641.text:
of walking they should do the new one-two-three-hop
she had learned at the kindergarten.

1648.text:
It was unheard-of conduct, but it was for
Yuki Chan, and father and mother stumped along,

1655.text:
cheered on by the small girl who was trying
to keep time, but was breathless through sheer

1660.text:
excess of happiness.
There was nothing in the room to impede their

1666.text:
progress. No chairs with treacherous legs
to trip over, no beds, nor tables with sharp

1672.text:
corners —nothing whatever but the matting,
soft and thick, where Yuki Chan had practised

1679.text:
all the gymnastics of childhood unbruised
and unharmed.

1683.text:
Half skipping, half hopping, and wholly undone
with laughter and exertion, the three at last

1690.text:
reached the place where, for six years, offerings
had been made for the gift of the child who

1695.text:
stood to these two for love.
Arranged in the best room in the house, on

1701.text:
five long red-covered shelves, were dolls.
Big dolls and little dolls, thin ones and

1707.text:
fat ones, each one to represent some royal
man or woman of the long ago, and dressed

1714.text:
in a fashion of a time almost forgotten. There
was Jimmu Tenno, the first real emperor. His

1722.text:
hair was done in a curious fashion and his
dress was of a wonderful brocade, while his

1728.text:
hands clasped two fierce-looking swords. There
was Jingo, too, who had won fame and lasting

1734.text:
honor by her wonderful fighting, and was so
great she had to sit by the emperors and look

1740.text:
down on the other empresses. Such a lot of
them! Some worthy to be remembered every day

1746.text:
in the year, others the more quickly forgotten
the better.

1751.text:
Yuki Chan knew them all by heart, and she
lingered before those she liked and quickly

1756.text:
passed those she did not care for. She could
not be rude to an emperor, even though he

1762.text:
had been dead hundreds of years. She was really
not very afraid of the greatness of the old

1768.text:
doll men and women who sat on the shelf, still
it was well to be careful about handling them.

1775.text:
She might be turned into a lizard or a snake,
just as the old lodge-keeper had said.

1781.text:
But her delight was in the miniature toilet
articles of solid silver, costly gold lacquer,

1787.text:
and porcelain, so tiny, so beautifully carved
they must have meant the eyesight of some

1794.text:
workman, only too glad to shut out the sunlight
forever if he might produce just one perfect

1799.text:
thing.
The things, however, that made Yuki Chan clap

1803.text:
her hands and the nesting birds perk up their
heads at the sound of her clear, sweet laugh

1809.text:
were the funny little lacquer carts in which
the royalty was supposed to ride, drawn by

1815.text:
impossible fat bullocks, so bow-legged that
their curves formed a big round O. Yuki Chan

1822.text:
made her red lips into the same shape, and
called her mother to look.

1828.text:
She pretended to feed the dolls with real
food and wine, and actually played with the

1833.text:
five court musicians, because they were partly
servants and it did not matter.

1838.text:
Her tongue ran in ceaseless chatter. Her father
and mother hovered around her, repeating the

1845.text:
history of all those wonderful people. Yuki
Chan listened very little, so concerned was

1851.text:
she with her own comments, until she happened
to see an anxious look creep into her mother's

1857.text:
eyes. It was something every little girl must
know, and if Yuki Chan's honorable ears refused

1863.text:
to open, how would she learn? Then Yuki Chan
nestled close, and gave little pats of love

1871.text:
and tried to listen. THE shadows of the bamboo
grew long and slim as the sun kissed them

1878.text:
good night. The sails skimmed homeward on
a silver sea as the west covered its rosy

1884.text:
pink in a veil of deepest blue. The young
birds in the old plum-tree did not stir at

1891.text:
the loving touch of the mother who, with a
soft bill, searched and sought for the lost

1896.text:
one. The plum-blossoms lingered yet for a
night as the air had grown chill.

1902.text:
Within the house Yuki Chan, still dressed,
lay on the floor, weary with the wonders of

1907.text:
the day. Her mother took from a small inclosure
beneath a shelf many soft comforts with which

1914.text:
she arranged the child's bed. Yuki Chan, talking
all the time in a low monotone, tried to unravel

1920.text:
a tangle in her mind of birds and cats and
dolls. It was all getting unmanageable and

1927.text:
very hazy, when her mother gathered her into
her arms, and quickly casting aside her two

1932.text:
garments laid her gently in a bath of caressing
warmth. A moment more and the little maiden

1939.text:
lay like a rose-leaf in her bed.
The night-lamp made shadowy ghosts of all

1945.text:
it touched, and one gleam of light, escaping
the paper shade, hung like an aureole above

1951.text:
the head of Yuki Chan's mother as she knelt
with clasped hands before the Buddha on the

1959.text:
shelf.
Her moving lips had only one refrain: "The

1961.text:
child, the child, the child."
Yuki Chan watched the play of the light in

1968.text:
the half-dark room. What funny things those
shadows made, and, strangely enough, one more

1975.text:
wonderful than all the rest grew into the
shape of the boy, and his lips were saying,

1982.text:
"Be good."
Then Yuki Chan lost herself in a mist of drowsiness,

1987.text:
and her mother sat by, and kept time with
her hand as she chanted rather than sang:

1994.text:
"Sleep, little one, sleep.
The sparrows are nodding.

1997.text:
Beneath the deep willow-trees
The night-lamp is burning.

2003.text:
Sleep, little one, sleep."
End of Chapter II

2010.text:
CHAPTER III
Recording by Rebecca Braunert-Plunkett

2016.text:
Twelve times had the plum-tree scattered its
petals to the wind, and Yuki San had passed

2022.text:
from childhood into girlhood, and had already
touched the border of that grave land of grown-up,

2029.text:
where all the worries lie. For though she
was apparently only a larger edition of the

2036.text:
spoiled, impulsive happy child of old, yet
often her eyes were shadowed with the struggle

2042.text:
of shielding her aging father and mother from
the poverty that was coming closer day by

2047.text:
day.
During the three years she had been gaining

2051.text:
her education at the English mission-school,
they had toiled unceasingly that she might

2057.text:
have the best the country could afford, but
now that she had returned after her long struggle

2063.text:
with a strange language and a strange people,
it was but fitting that she should take up

2069.text:
her duties as the daughter of an impoverished
family of high rank. The father, grown old

2075.text:
and feeble, gave up the battle for existence,
and being a devout Buddhist, turned his thoughts

2081.text:
upon Nirvana, which he strove diligently to
enter by perpetual meditation and prayer.

2088.text:
The mother, used to guidance and unable to
think or plan for herself, turned helplessly

2095.text:
to Yuki San.
The duties were heavy for girlish shoulders,

2100.text:
and often as the dawn crept over the mountains
it found the girl wide-eyed and still, trying

2107.text:
to solve the problem of modest demand and
meager supply.

2112.text:
She had learned many things at the mission-school.
She could read and write English imperfectly,

2118.text:
she could recite the multiplication table
faster than any one else, she could perform

2124.text:
the most intricate figures in physical culture,
and if she had infinite time she could play

2130.text:
three hymns on the organ. These varied accomplishments,
however, seemed of little assistance in showing

2138.text:
her how to stretch her father's small pension
beyond the barest necessities of the household.

2145.text:
Tales had been told her of a great land, far
beyond her sea-bound home, where women of

2150.text:
the highest birth went out to work in the
busy world. How she had marveled at their

2155.text:
boldness and wondered at the customs that
would permit it! Now she half envied them

2161.text:
their freedom, and sighed over the iron-bound
etiquette that forbade a departure from her

2166.text:
father's roof save for the inevitable end
of all Japanese women—a prearranged marriage.

2172.text:
It was for this she had been so carefully
trained in all phases of housekeeping, and

2178.text:
in all the intricacies of social life. Her
education from birth had been with a view

2186.text:
of making smooth the path of her future husband
that his home might be peaceful and he untroubled.

2193.text:
Each day as the burden grew heavier she fought
her battle with the bravery and courage of

2199.text:
youth. With jests and chatter she served her
parents' simple meals, constantly urging them

2205.text:
to further indulgence of what she pretended
was a great feast, but which in reality she

2212.text:
had secretly sacrificed some household treasure
to obtain. She deftly turned the rice-bucket

2218.text:
as she served, that they might not see the
scant supply. With great ceremony she poured

2224.text:
the hot water into the bowls, insisting that
no other sake was made such as this. Her determination

2232.text:
to keep them happy and ignorant of the true
conditions taxed her every resource, but it

2238.text:
was her duty, and duty to Yuki San was the
only religion of which she was sure.

2245.text:
But one day a great event happened in the
little home. Yuki San was called before her

2251.text:
father and told, in ceremonious language,
that a marriage had been arranged for her

2257.text:
with Saito San, a wealthy officer in the Emperor's
household. She laid her head upon the mats

2263.text:
and gave thanks to the gods. Now her father
and mother would live in luxury for the rest

2269.text:
of their lives!
Saito San was to her only a far-away, shadowy

2275.text:
being, whom she was to obey for the rest of
her life and whose house she was to keep in

2281.text:
order. He was a means to an end, and entered
into her thoughts merely as one to whom she

2287.text:
was deeply grateful. Youth and all its joys
were strong within her, and the pressure of

2293.text:
poverty gone, her whole nature rebounded with
delight.

2299.text:
Many times had marriage been proposed for
her, for the story of her beauty and obedience

2304.text:
had spread, but her father guarded his treasure
zealously, and it was not until an offer came,

2311.text:
suiting his former rank and condition, that
he gave his consent.

2315.text:
Now, when he saw the happy light in the eyes
of his child, and saw the color come into

2320.text:
her cheeks, he laid his hands upon her head
and blessed her. When Yuki San was by herself

2327.text:
she clapped her hands joyfully. "I make happy
like 'Merican," she whispered. "Hooray, hooray!

2335.text:
now my troublesome make absence," and she
hurried away to put a thank-offering before

2341.text:
the household god.
Having arranged all preliminaries and instructed

2346.text:
the mother to sell every household treasure
that his child's clothes might do honor to

2352.text:
the rich man's house, the father went back
once more to his pipe and his dreams.

2359.text:
Yuki San and her mother were up with the sun,
sewing and embroidering, and going about their

2364.text:
daily task with zest and song. The past trials
were forgotten and the future not considered.

2373.text:
One morning, not many weeks after the marriage
had been arranged, Yuki San heard the call

2378.text:
of the Yubin San, and running out to meet
him, received a strange-looking letter. The

2385.text:
envelope was white and square, and straight
across the middle, in very plain English,

2391.text:
was her name and address. Puzzled, she turned
it over and over, then broke the seal.

2398.text:
The picture of the big hotel at the top of
the sheet was so distracting that for a time

2403.text:
she could get no further, but a word here
and there and the signature at the end finally

2410.text:
made her cry out with delight and surprise.
"Oh! it's from that funny lil' boy what gave

2417.text:
spank to my hands long time ago. He want to
come to my house for stay. Listen."

2423.text:
There was no one to listen but her own happy
self, and lying flat upon the floor she propped

2429.text:
her glowing face between her palms, while
she read aloud from the letter spread before

2436.text:
Miss YUKI INOUYE—
Dear Miss Inouye: I wonder if you remember

2441.text:
an American boy with whom you had an encounter
in your very early days, because he dared

2447.text:
to thwart your plans concerning a cat? I remember
it very well, and the jolly picnics and excursions

2454.text:
that you and my mother and I took together
afterward.

2459.text:
I hope you have not forgotten me, for I am
going to claim the privilege of the conqueror

2464.text:
in that old battle and ask a favor of you.
My Government has sent me out to your country

2470.text:
on some important business, and finding there
was no hotel close to my work, I wrote to

2476.text:
the school where my mother and I visited twelve
years ago, and asked them to recommend a family

2483.text:
that would be good enough to take me in for
two months. Strangely enough your father's

2489.text:
name was suggested, and when I read that the
only daughter both spoke and wrote English,

2496.text:
and that her name was Yuki San, my mind flew
back to my "Little Sister Snow" of the days

2501.text:
gone by.
Could your father manage to accommodate me

2505.text:
for a couple of months, if I promise to be
very good and take up as little room as possible?

2511.text:
If you think he can, please wire me here at
Yokohama, and I'll come straight down.

2517.text:
Hoping to see you very soon, I am
Your old friend,

2521.text:
RICHARD MELTON MERRIT.
Yuki San turned the letter this way and that,

2527.text:
and vainly tried to decipher the strange words.
It was undoubtedly English, but not the English

2534.text:
she was used to. She ran for her small dictionary
and diligently searched out the meaning of

2540.text:
each phrase.
Yes, she remembered the boy—he had light

2544.text:
hair, and blue eyes that laughed, and he was
a big, big boy and carried her on his shoulder.

2551.text:
She sat with the folded letter clasped carefully
in her hands and gave herself up to joyous

2557.text:
anticipation. A foreign guest was coming to
stay two whole months in her house; after

2563.text:
that she was to be married and wear her beautiful
kimono, and give rich gifts to her father

2568.text:
and mother.
Surely Buddha was caring for her! There had

2573.text:
been grave moments of doubt about it since
she left the mission-school, for he had never

2578.text:
seemed to listen, though she prayed him night
and day. But he had been only waiting to send

2585.text:
all her happiness at once—he was a good
god, kind and thoughtful. To-morrow, before

2592.text:
the sun touched the big pine-tree on the mountain-top,
she would go to the temple and tell him so.

2598.text:
Yuki San's plans found favor with her parents,
chiefly because of their great desire to give

2603.text:
her pleasure, and incidentally because the
board of the foreigner would swell the fund

2609.text:
that was needed for her marriage.
The plighted maid to them was already the

2614.text:
wife, and the danger of a youthful heart defying
tradition and clearing the bars of conventionality

2622.text:
to reach its own desire was something unknown
to these simple people. The child wished the

2628.text:
foreigner to come—they could give her few
pleasures—she should have her desire.

2634.text:
The sending of the telegram was the first
exciting thing to be attended to. Five times

2640.text:
Yuki San rewrote the short message, finding
her fingers less deft than her tongue in framing

2645.text:
an English sentence. Gravely and with effort
she wrote:

2650.text:
"I give you all my house. Your lovely friend,
Yuki."

2655.text:
But she shook her head over this and tried
again:

2658.text:
"You have the welcome of my heart. Yuki."
This, too, fell short of her ideal, so she

2665.text:
decided to send simply two words of which
she was quite sure:

2670.text:
"Please come."
The days that followed were crowded with busy

2674.text:
preparation. The difficulty of providing the
ease and comfort that the presence of so honorable

2681.text:
a guest demanded taxed to the utmost Yuki
San's resourceful nature. Gaily she set her

2687.text:
wits and fingers to work—placing a heavy
brass hibachi over a black scorch in the matting,

2693.text:
fitting new rice-paper into the small wooden
squares of the shoji, and hanging kakemono

2698.text:
over the ugly holes made by the missing plaster
in the wall.

2702.text:
From one part of the house to another she
flitted, laughing and working, while the old

2707.text:
garden echoed her happiness and overflowed
with blossom and song.

2712.text:
On the day of Merrit's expected arrival, when
the last flower had been put in the vases,

2717.text:
and the last speck of dust flecked from the
matting, Yuki San's keen eyes detected a torn

2723.text:
place in the paper door which separated the
guest-chamber from the narrow hall.

2728.text:
A puzzled little frown drew her black brows
together, but it soon fled before her smile.

2735.text:
"Ah!" she cried, "idea come quickly! I write
picture of bamboo on teared place."

2741.text:
With paint and brush she fell to work, and
beneath her skilful fingers the ugly tear

2747.text:
disappeared in a forest of slender take which
stretched away to the foot of a snow-capped

2752.text:
mountain.
With a last touch she sank back on her heels

2756.text:
and viewed her work with deep satisfaction.
"All finished," she said, opening wide her

2762.text:
arms; "no more to do now but wait for that
time 'Merican sensei call jollyful!"

2769.text:
A laugh behind her made her turn her head
quickly, and there in the doorway stood a

2775.text:
tall foreigner, with outstretched hand of
welcome.

2779.text:
Hand-shaking was an unknown art with Yuki
San, so after one startled upward glance she

2785.text:
touched her head to the floor in gracious
courtesy.

2789.text:
All her gay spirits and freedom of speech
vanished, and she was instantly enveloped

2794.text:
in a mist of shyness and reserve that Merrit's
direct look did not serve to lessen.

2800.text:
With lowered eyes, she ushered him into the
larger living-room, and bade him be seated

2805.text:
and accept all the hospitality her father's
poor house could give.

2810.text:
After a long and tiresome journey Merrit found
something inexpressibly charming in the quiet,

2816.text:
picturesque place, and in the silent young
girl who sat so demurely in the shadow. He

2822.text:
tactfully ignored her timidity by talking
cheerful nonsense about impersonal things,

2827.text:
treating her as a bashful child who wanted
to be friends but hardly dared.

2833.text:
As he talked Yuki San gained courage, and
ventured many curious glances at the broad-shouldered

2840.text:
young fellow, whose figure seemed completely
to fill the room. At first she saw only a

2846.text:
strange foreigner, but gradually, as she watched
his face and listened to his unfamiliar speech,

2852.text:
she discovered a long-lost playmate.
Through all the years that she had struggled

2857.text:
for an education at the mission-school, English
had been invariably associated with a tall,

2863.text:
awkward, foreign boy, whose mouth made funny
curves and whose eyes laughed when he made

2868.text:
strange sounds. How big and splendid and handsome
he had grown! How different his clothes from

2875.text:
any she had ever seen before! How white his
long hands, whose strong, firm touch she remembered

2881.text:
so well! She looked and looked again, drinking
in the tones of his deep voice, till the throbbing

2887.text:
of her heart sent a flood of crimson to her
cheeks.

2891.text:
But gradually her shyness wore away, and when
Merrit asked her how in the world he was to

2897.text:
conduct his business with so few Japanese
words at his command, she ventured to answer:

2903.text:
"I know; I give you the teach of Nippon, you
give me the wise of dat funny 'Merican tongue."

2909.text:
"That's a go!" said Dick, as he held out his
hand to close the bargain.

2914.text:
But the girl drew back, troubled.
"No, no, you no go! You stay. I give you all

2922.text:
my intellect of Nippon speech. Please!" and
she looked up pleadingly.

2927.text:
Merrit laughed outright.
"That's all right, Yuki San; I am going to

2932.text:
stay, and we will begin school in the morning."
By this time the mother and father had learned

2939.text:
of the guest's arrival and hurried in to bid
him welcome. The unpacking of his steamer-trunk

2945.text:
and the disposal of his possessions in his
small apartment was a matter of interest to

2951.text:
the whole family. Each article was politely
examined and exclaimed over, and when Merrit

2957.text:
drew out a package of photographs and showed
them his home and family and friends, the

2963.text:
excitement became intense.
That night Yuki San lay once more on her soft

2969.text:
futon and watched the shadow of the night-lamp
play upon the screens. Nothing was changed

2975.text:
in the homely room since she had lain there
in her babyhood: the same little lamp, the

2981.text:
same little Buddha on the shelf looking at
her with inscrutable eyes.

2987.text:
Yuki San stirred restlessly. "Dat most nice
girl in picture," she said to herself. "Him

2994.text:
make marry with dat girl, he say." Then she
added inconsequently, with a sigh, "I much

3002.text:
hope Saito San go to war for long, long time."
End of Chapter III

3012.text:
CHAPTER IV
For two halcyon months Yuki San lived in a

3018.text:
dream. The ample compensation Merrit insisted
upon making for the hospitality extended to

3024.text:
him more than met the modest needs of the
little household, and once again, as in the

3029.text:
earlier days, they went on jolly excursions,
visited ancient temples, and picnicked under

3036.text:
the shadow of the torii. The father and mother
always trotted close behind, and Yuki San,

3042.text:
vastly pleased with her ability, gaily translated
the speeches from one to another. She talked

3049.text:
incessantly, laughing over her own mistakes,
and growing prettier and more winsome every

3054.text:
day.
Merrit was glad to fill his leisure time in

3058.text:
such pleasant companionship. Yuki San was
the same little bundle of charm he remembered

3063.text:
of old, with her innocence untouched, and
a heart whose depths had never yet been stirred.

3069.text:
He teased her, and taught her, and played
with her, as he would have played with a merry

3074.text:
child. Naturally gentle and affectionate,
he unconsciously swept Yuki San to the borderland

3080.text:
of that golden world where to awaken alone
is agony.

3086.text:
One morning, when the heavy mists of the valley
lay in masses of pink against the deeper purple

3091.text:
of the mountain, and his Highness, the sun,
his face flushed from his long climb, was

3097.text:
sending his first glances over the sunny peaks
of Fuji-yama, Yuki San arose, after a sleepless

3104.text:
night, and faced the morning with sorrowful
eyes.

3107.text:
"You ve'y lazy, Mister Sun, this morning,"
she said, shaking a finger at him in reproof;

3113.text:
"where you the have been? Why you not come
the more early and make light for my busy?"

3120.text:
She tied the long sleeves of her bright kimono
out of her way, and twisting a bit of cloth

3125.text:
about her head, fell to dusting the shoji
and setting the small room in order.

3131.text:
"I must the hurry," she said, as she kept
up her brisk dusting. "I make the food so

3137.text:
quick as that Robin San steal berry for his
babies. To-day him one big, big day, but him

3146.text:
no glad day. Merrit San go away." She paused
in her work, and a look of pain darkened her

3153.text:
eyes, but she shook her head reproachfully.
"Ah, Yuki San, you make sorry voice and your

3161.text:
heart is thinking tears. You naughty girl!
Quick you make the fire to rise in hibachi

3168.text:
and give that Merrit San his gohan—same
thing what that funny 'Merica call breakfast."

3175.text:
After the steam had begun to rise from the
vessels on several hibachi, Yuki San, flushed

3181.text:
by her exertions, rested upon her heels before
the door that led into the garden. As she

3187.text:
fanned her flushed face with her sleeve, she
glanced again and again toward the narrow

3192.text:
stairway that led to the chamber above, and
at the slightest sound she listened in smiling

3198.text:
expectancy.
From outside the wall came the gentle slip-slap

3202.text:
of the water against the sampan, and the cheerful
banter of the owners as they made ready for

3208.text:
the work of the day.
Circling the garden, the fern-like maples

3213.text:
made a note of vivid crimson amid the feathery
green of the bamboo. Every feature of the

3219.text:
place was closely associated with her short
happy life. She had learned to walk on the

3225.text:
soft sandy paths, she had spelled out her
first characters on the old stone-lantern.

3232.text:
She had whispered her secrets to the broken-nosed
image of Kwannon, who sat in the shadow of

3237.text:
the pines, and there under the plum-tree she
had caught the naughty kitten that first brought

3242.text:
her and Merrit San together.
As she sat, with folded hands, and watched

3250.text:
the sunshine on the dewy leaves and flowers,
her intense, restless, vivacious body relaxed

3257.text:
in sudden languor and her soft mouth drooped
in wistfulness.

3263.text:
A splash in the pool below attracted her,
and looking down she saw the gleaming bodies

3268.text:
of the goldfish as they leaped into the air.
Instantly she was all life and volubility.

3274.text:
"Yuki San one big bad girl; she no remember
li'l fish. They always like hungry baby San

3282.text:
in early morning. I make fast to fill big
hole inside—ve'y li'l outside."

3289.text:
Slipping her half-stockinged feet out of her
straw house-shoes, she stepped into her wooden

3295.text:
geta, and passing a shelf, filled her hands
with round rice-cakes.

3300.text:
The edge of the water turned to gold as the
fish crowded close. Yuki San scattered the

3306.text:
crumbs and stood watching the wriggling mass
for a moment, then said:

3311.text:
"You ve'y greedy li'l fish. I never no can
fill your bodies. Now I get flower for Merrit

3318.text:
San's breakfast."
She made her way over the flat mossy stones,

3323.text:
passed the miniature Fuji where dwelt the
spirit of the wondrous "Lady who made the

3327.text:
flowers to bloom." She paused before the gorgeous
chrysanthemums and looked long at the morning-glories,

3333.text:
with their tender tints of dawn. But at last
she spied on a rose-bush, set apart from the

3340.text:
rest, a single white rose with a heart of
red.

3345.text:
With a little cry of satisfaction, she thrust
her hands among the thorns to pluck it. The

3351.text:
rebound of the bush sent fluttering to her
feet a brilliant purple butterfly. Tender

3356.text:
to all living things, Yuki San dropped quickly
to her knees and folded the half-chilled creature

3361.text:
between the palms of her warm hands.
"Ah, Cho Cho San," she said, "the day of yesterday

3368.text:
you so big and strong. The morning of to-day
you have the weakness of cold body. That Jack

3374.text:
Floss him ve'y naughty boy!"
She put her moist red lips to her folded palms

3381.text:
and the warmth of her breath stirred to action
the gauzy creature she held captive.

3387.text:
"You no must kick, Cho Cho San! Have the patience.
I make you warm, I give you one more day of

3395.text:
happy."
Yuki San's wooden shoes sent a sharp click

3400.text:
into the quiet morning air as she quickly
crossed the arched bridge and followed the

3405.text:
path to the stone image beyond the pool. With
a touch as soft as the wings she held, the

3412.text:
girl lightly balanced the now thoroughly warmed
butterfly on the broad forehead of the Goddess

3417.text:
of Mercy.
In sharp contrast to the spirit of the scene

3422.text:
came the clear, rollicking strains of an American
air, whistled by some one coming down the

3428.text:
steps.
For a moment Yuki San stood motionless, pressing

3432.text:
her lips softly to the rose she held. Then,
with a swift pitter-patter, she ran back to

3438.text:
the house.
"The top of the morning to the honorable Miss

3442.text:
Snow," said Merrit, who quite filled the doorway.
Not willing to be surpassed in salutation,

3450.text:
Yuki San laid a hand on each knee, and bending
her back at right angles, replied with mock

3455.text:
gravity:
"Ohayo Gozaimasu-Kyo wa yoi O tenki."

3463.text:
Merrit knew she had him at a disadvantage
in her own language, but, always delighted

3468.text:
to see the play of her dimples and the soft
pink creep into her cheeks when he teased,

3474.text:
he stood by her now, big and stern, and growling.
"See here, Yuki San, otherwise Miss Snow,

3482.text:
you just come off your high stilts of that
impossible lingo, and speak nice English suitable

3487.text:
for a little boy like me to understand."
"Li'l boy like you!" she rippled, "li'l boy

3493.text:
like you! Merrit San him so long when he make
Japanese bow he come down from top like big

3501.text:
bamboo-tree—so!" Putting her hands high
above her head, she bent till the tips of

3507.text:
her fingers touched the floor. Still bent,
she twisted her head till her eyes, bright

3513.text:
with laughter, looked straight into Merrit's.
He lifted his eyebrows quizzically. "See here,

3520.text:
Yuki San, you are fast developing the symptoms
of a coquette."

3525.text:
She quickly straightened her back, and with
a smile of bewilderment, exclaimed:

3529.text:
"Me croquette? No, no; croquette, him li'l
chicken-ball what you eat. I no can be eat!"

3537.text:
Merrit shouted with delight, then grew grave.
"No, Yuki San, you don't ever want to be a

3543.text:

her, but now even the preparations, which

her. No thought of evading her duty crossed

love. How it make the change in whole earth
and life and give the dance of heart. But

5212.text:
I will not. Mens and women of Japanese country
have not the understand of such lovely thing,

5220.text:
and make the shameful of me. So I give silence
to my lips and close the door of my heart.

5226.text:
Ah, what funny little thing that heart is!
In one half live the joyful. Other side have

5233.text:
all the painful of life, and when the love
come sometimes he knock at wrong door and

5239.text:
give the hurtful ache to life. Ah, Merrit
San, you give many thankfuls for the lend

5247.text:
of my house in your letter. I give the love
of you many more thankfuls for coming to my

5253.text:
heart, even he knock at two doors. One day
me and Merrit San went down to temple where

5261.text:
big feast was. Merrit San go inside and look
long long time at Buddha, then he say:

5268.text:
"Yuki San, what will this old gentleman do
to you if you disobey him?" I give little

5274.text:
think, then I say, "I no can know—I no never
disobey. Buddha say, 'Yuki, take care father

5283.text:
and mother all time.' I take care. Him say,
'Yuki, you woman—you not talk too much.'

5291.text:
I no talk much. Then him say, 'Yuki, come
many time to temple and make light with incense

5299.text:
and put little money every time in box.' I
give obey and much go rin, but Buddha keep

5306.text:
all and never give back." Before I finish
my speak Merrit San shiver like cold and say,

5314.text:
"Come on, Yuki San, let's get out of here
and find the sun." Outside I make cherry-wreath

5321.text:
while Merrit San tell me story. Him very sweet
day—now all gone forever.

5331.text:
Seventh Entry
Last fine kimono is finished and all baggage

5337.text:
is tied. Next day I go to other house.
Then my mother will give all house much sweep

5344.text:
with new broom, to tell gods I go 'way no
more to come back. Maybe they make big fire

5351.text:
by gate to tell all peoples I belong to other
house now. Ah, little book, to-night I make

5358.text:
big fire in my heart and burn all my wickeds
in it. Next day I make more fire and burn

5365.text:
you. To other house I must go all white and
purely as Merrit San say.

5371.text:
Ah, Merrit San, you the one big happy in all
my life and I never forget all your kindful.

5379.text:
You give me the good heart, like sun make
flower-bud unclose. You telled me what is

5385.text:
soul and purely, and you say be very good
wife.

5390.text:
One night when moon was big and round and
red and river outside wall go spank, spank,

5397.text:
you call all my people to garden, and with
the 'Merican samisen you sing much songs.

5403.text:
Sometimes you very funny, but sometimes when
moon specks slip through big pine-tree, I

5410.text:
see you very sadful.
Now moon speck come on shoji and ache my eyes

5416.text:
to look your face once more.
I try so much to make picture of man's face

5422.text:
I marry with. I no can see anything but much
medals on coat, and so many teeths. Merrit

5429.text:
San's eyes all blue and twinkly, and face
so white and clean.

5435.text:
But now he make the joyful with girl with
laugh in her eyes, and her feet no touch the

5440.text:
ground with much happy.
To-morrow I go to other house and no belong

5445.text:
to my father and mother. To-day I go temple,
and I make promise I no more speak of Merrit

5452.text:
San's name; no more the think of his face
in my heart.

5457.text:
Little book, I weared you close to my breast
many days. To-night I sleep with you tight

5462.text:
to my heart. You gived me the courage to turn
my face to the rising sun of the to-morrow.

5475.text:
CHAPTER VII
Recording by Anastasiia Solokha

5481.text:
The low, deep music of a temple bell rolled
down the hillside and echoed through the giant

5489.text:
cryptomerias. It stirred to action the creatures
of the early dawn and passed out with infinite

5495.text:
sweetness to the red-rimmed east of another
day.

5498.text:
The priests in the old temples chanted their
prayers with weird monotony, while a single

5505.text:
bird poured out his morning song of love at
the door of his mate.

5511.text:
The old stone steps leading from temple to
temple would have looked as they had a thousand

5517.text:
other mornings, gray, grim, and mossy, save
for a little figure that slowly took its way

5523.text:
up a long and crooked flight.
Yuki San was on her way to make good her promise

5530.text:
to the gods. Her wooden shoes clicked sharply
in the quiet morning air, then hushed as she

5536.text:
paused for rest on a broad step. Even the
exertion of the long climb had failed to color

5542.text:
her white cheeks, but her lips were carmine
and her eyes luminous with purpose.

5549.text:
The one spot of color about her otherwise
sober little figure was a bright-red furoshike

5555.text:
held close, in which something was carefully
wrapped.

5560.text:
A noisy waterfall leaped past her down the
hillside in a perpetual challenge to race

5564.text:
to the foot. Stern-faced images, grim of aspect,
stared at her as she climbed, but Yuki San

5572.text:
kept gravely on her way until she reached
the open door of the great silent temple.

5578.text:
The faint light of the early morning had scarce
penetrated the shadows that clung about the

5583.text:
gorgeous hangings and rich symbols of this
ancient place of worship. A white-robed priest,

5590.text:
oblivious to all save his own meditations,
paid little heed to the childlike figure as

5595.text:
it knelt before the cold, calm, unchanging
image of the great Buddha.

5601.text:
For a moment Yuki San moved her lips. Still
kneeling, she drew from her sash the red furoshike

5608.text:
and took from it a small morocco note-book.
With light steps she crossed to a brazier,

5615.text:
and with a pair of small tongs lifted from
it a glowing coal. With steady fingers she

5620.text:
pushed aside the many sticks of incense in
the great brass vessel before the shrine,

5626.text:
and making a little grave among the ashes,
she laid within the burning coal the little

5631.text:
book.
The blue smoke, rising slowly, hung for a

5634.text:
moment above the girl's head as a halo, then
rose to the feet of Buddha as in supplication

5641.text:
for mercy, and was finally lost in the darkness
of the heavy roof.

5645.text:
The girl watched with wide eyes and parted
lips. Clasping her hands, she lifted her face

5653.text:
and from her heart came a fervent, whispered
prayer.

5657.text:
"I make empty my heart of all wicked. Buddha
or Christians' God, I no can know which. Please

5667.text:
the more better speak into my lonely life
the word of peace."

5673.text:
She turned from the silent temple on her homeward
way. She paused by the clump of bamboo where

5679.text:
so short a time before she had gleefully tied
together two boughs in the name of Merrit

5685.text:
and herself. Tiptoeing to reach the high boughs
which Merrit had held for her to tie, she

5691.text:
drew them downward to slip the thong that
bound them. After holding them to her soft

5699.text:
cheek a moment, she let them fly apart, while
she closed her eyes and whispered softly:

5709.text:
"Good-by, beautiful love, good-by."
End of Chapter VII
